title: Lyme Regis to West Bay Walk Route

nearby.description: Lyme Regis to Seaton Undercliff Walk
Circular Walk from West Bay Dorset

images.title: Trevor Rickard / The Spittles
images.caption: The Spittles. View north-east from Lyme Regis sea front to The Spittles at low tide.

images.title: Paul Allison / A view from East Cliff Beach across to Charmouth and Stonebarrow Hill
images.caption: A view from East Cliff Beach across to Charmouth and Stonebarrow Hill. This image is taken from the last concrete groyne on what is officially known as "East Cliff Beach" but known locally as "Back Beach". You can see the Sandstone begin at the top of the Blue Lias land mass on the left hand side of the picture.

images.title: Simon Norman / Cain's Folly
images.caption: Cain's Folly, located just east of Charmouth. Here you can see the ruins of WW2 radar stations, destroyed in 1942 landslide.

images.title: Ian Capper / Towards Golden Cap
images.caption: Towards Golden Cap. Viewed from the cliffs above Charmouth. The coastal path used to run here, but has now been diverted inland because of loss of the clifftop to landslides over the years.

images.title: Roger Cornfoot / Langdon Woods, from Golden Cap
images.caption: Langdon Woods, from Golden Cap

images.title: Jim Champion / Beach at Eype's Mouth
images.caption: Beach at Eype Mouth located near West Bay. Looking west along the shingle beach at Eype's Mouth, with Thorncombe Beacon in the middle distance. In the far distance, across the bay, is the start of the Devon coast, around Lyme Regis.

description: This walk takes you along the Jurassic Coast from Lyme Regis to West Bay. It runs for just over 8 miles and uses public footpaths and the waymarked South West Coast Path. Along the way there's lovely beaches, pretty coastal villages and wonderful views from the cliff top paths. The walk starts in Lyme Regis and heads east along the beach towards Charmouth. It's advisable to check the tide times for this section as if it is high tide you will need to take the South West Coast path trail above the beach. From Charmouth you continue east to Cain's Folly, Broom Cliff and the Golden Cap Estate. This area is one of the highlights of the south coast with breathtaking views from the elevated position of the Cap. After descending the hill you continue east past Chideock, Seatown, Thorncombe Beacon, East Ebb Cove and Lower Eype before finishing at West Bay. It's a very picturesque spot sited at the mouth of the River Brit just south of the town of Bridport. You may recognise the scenery in the area as some of the ITV drama "Broadchurch" was filmed here.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: On the walk you could stop off at the Beach Cafe at Charmouth. There's a good range of meals, snacks and locally made cakes. Next to the cafe there's also the Charmouth Heritage Coast Centre where you can see a wonderful fossil collection including an ichthyosaur that starred in the BBC documentary ‘Attenborough and the Sea Dragon’. There's also guided fossil hunting walks to try here.At West Bay at the end of the route you can reward yourself with some refreshments at The George. The pub is in a great location on the harbour and includes a riverside terrace for warmer days. It's also dog friendly if you have your canine friend with you. You can find it at 18 George Street with a postcode of DT6 4HA for your sat navs.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: To continue your walking in the area you could pick up the Circular Walk from West Bay and visit the nearby village of Burton Bradstock. You can also pick up the Chesil Beach Walk near here. Head a few miles inland and you could try the National Trust's Lamberts Castle to Coneys Castle Walk. The walk visits historic old hill forts where you can enjoy some stunning views over the countryside of the Marshwood Vale. Near Bridport there's the climb to the lovely viewpoint at Colmers Hill from the picturesque village of Symondsbury. The historic village includes an ancient church and a noteworthy 15th century, thatched pub. For more walking ideas in the area see the Dorset Walks page.

display_address: Long Entry, Lyme Regis, Dorset, England, DT7 3QB, United Kingdom
